title: Leo Penn
text:
Leonard Francis Penn (August 27, 1921 – September 5, 1998) was an American actor and <a href="Television%20director">director</a> and the father of musician <a href="Michael%20Penn">Michael Penn</a> and actors <a href="Sean%20Penn">Sean Penn</a> and <a href="Chris%20Penn">Chris Penn</a>.
Early life.
Penn was born in <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Massachusetts">Lawrence, Massachusetts</a>, the son of <a href="Russian-Jewish">Russian-Jewish</a> immigrants Elizabeth (<a href="married%20and%20maiden%20names">née</a> Melincoff) and Maurice Daniel Penn (<a href="Lithuanian-Jewish">Lithuanian-Jewish</a> family).
Penn served in the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">United States Army Air Forces</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> as a <a href="B-24%20Liberator">B-24 Liberator</a> bombardier with the 755th Bomb Squadron, 458th Bomb Group, stationed in <a href="England">England</a> as part of the <a href="Eighth%20Air%20Force">Eighth Air Force</a>.
Career.
A life member of <a href="Actors%20Studio">The Actors Studio</a>, Penn won the <a href="Theatre%20World%20Award">Theatre World Award</a> in 1954 for his performance in the play "The Girl on the Via Flaminia". He acted in numerous roles in the early years of television. In 1956, he was cast as Mr. Rico in the episode "Ringside Padre" of the religion <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a>, "<a href="Crossroads%20%281955%20TV%20series%29">Crossroads</a>". In 1957, he appeared in the episode "One If by Sea" of the military drama series, "<a href="Navy%20Log">Navy Log</a>". He was also cast in an episode of <a href="Beverly%20Garland">Beverly Garland</a>'s 1957-1958 groundbreaking <a href="crime%20drama">crime drama</a>, "<a href="Decoy%20%28TV%20series%29">Decoy</a>". In 1960, he played Cavage in "The Poker Fiend" on <a href="Richard%20Boone">Richard Boone</a>'s <a href="CBS">CBS</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series, "<a href="Have%20Gun%20%E2%80%93%20Will%20Travel">Have Gun – Will Travel</a>." In 1961, he was cast as Tiko in the episode "The World Is Her Oyster" of the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> adventure series, "<a href="The%20Islanders%20%28TV%20series%29">The Islanders</a>", set in the <a href="Oceania">South Pacific</a>, and appeared in an episode of the ABC crime drama "<a href="The%20Asphalt%20Jungle%20%28TV%20series%29">The Asphalt Jungle</a>". He also appeared in another ABC adventure series, "<a href="Straightaway%20%28TV%20series%29">Straightaway</a>", which focuses on automobile racing. On March 3, 1961, he co-starred with <a href="Peter%20Falk">Peter Falk</a> and <a href="Joyce%20Van%20Patten">Joyce Van Patten</a> in the episode "Cold Turkey" of the ABC <a href="legal%20drama">legal drama</a> series, "<a href="The%20Law%20and%20Mr.%20Jones">The Law and Mr. Jones</a>" starring <a href="James%20Whitmore">James Whitmore</a>. About this time, he also appeared on <a href="Pat%20O%27Brien%20%28actor%29">Pat O'Brien</a>'s ABC sitcom, "<a href="Harrigan%20and%20Son">Harrigan and Son</a>". In the 1961-1962 television season Penn acted in the CBS crime drama, "<a href="Checkmate%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">Checkmate</a>" in the episode "The Button-Down Break" and starred as Jerry Green in <a href="Gertrude%20Berg">Gertrude Berg</a>'s CBS's <a href="situation%20comedy">sitcom</a> "<a href="Mrs.%20G.%20Goes%20to%20College">Mrs. G. Goes to College</a>" renamed at mid-season as "The Gertrude Berg Show".
Penn landed work as a director for many television series, including "<a href="I%20Spy%20%281965%20TV%20series%29">I Spy</a>", "<a href="Lost%20in%20Space">Lost in Space</a>", 
"<a href="Cannon">Cannon</a>"," ", "<a href="Blue%20Light%20%28TV%20series%29">Blue Light</a>", "<a href="Custer%20%28TV%20series%29">Custer</a>", the 1976 <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> "<a href="Sara%20%28U.S.%201976%20TV%20series%29">Sara</a>", "<a href="St.%20Elsewhere">St. Elsewhere</a>", "<a href="Kojak">Kojak</a>", "<a href="Starsky%20and%20Hutch">Starsky and Hutch</a>", "<a href="Cagney%20%26amp%3B%20Lacey">Cagney & Lacey</a>", "<a href="Little%20House%20on%20the%20Prairie%20%28TV%20series%29">Little House on the Prairie</a>", "<a href="Columbo%20%28TV%20series%29">Columbo</a>", "<a href="Hawaii%20Five-O%20%281968%20TV%20series%29">Hawaii Five-O</a>", "<a href="Trapper%20John%2C%20M.D.">Trapper John, M.D.</a>", <a href="Hart%20To%20Hart">Hart To Hart</a>, "<a href="Magnum%2C%20P.I.">Magnum, P.I.</a>" and "<a href="Father%20Murphy">Father Murphy</a>". In 1983, Penn was nominated for an <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmy Award</a> for Outstanding Directing in a Drama Series for "<a href="The%20Mississippi%20%28TV%20series%29">The Mississippi</a>".
Politics.
Penn supported the Hollywood trade unions and refused to accuse others to the <a href="House%20Un-American%20Activities%20Committee">House Un-American Activities Committee</a> in their investigation of suspected Communist infiltration of the film industry. Penn was subsequently <a href="Hollywood%20blacklist">blacklisted</a>, and Paramount refused to renew his contract. As a result, Penn was not able to work as a movie actor. He found acting work in television, but <a href="CBS">CBS</a> ousted him after receiving an anonymous accusation that he had addressed a Communist political meeting. Barred from acting in film or TV, he became a director.
Personal life.
His first marriage, to <a href="Olive%20Deering">Olive Deering</a>, was dissolved in 1952. He was married in 1957 to actress <a href="Eileen%20Ryan">Eileen Ryan</a>, with whom he had three sons: singer <a href="Michael%20Penn">Michael Penn</a>, and actors <a href="Sean%20Penn">Sean Penn</a> and <a href="Chris%20Penn">Chris Penn</a>. His granddaughter (his son Sean's daughter) is actress <a href="Dylan%20Penn">Dylan Penn</a>.
Leo Penn died of <a href="lung%20cancer">lung cancer</a> in <a href="Santa%20Monica%2C%20California">Santa Monica, California</a>, on September 5, 1998, at the age of 77, and was interred at the <a href="Holy%20Cross%20Cemetery%2C%20Culver%20City">Holy Cross Cemetery</a> in <a href="Culver%20City%2C%20California">Culver City</a>, California.
